Section 1: Child Development

Developmental Milestones

The next few pages will review the developmental milestones for children at various stages.. Please note that these are only a few of the examples of skills and ages. There are much more detailed tools for you to use to monitor developmental milestones. Several of these resources are identified in the support material section of this section.

Things To Remember About Child Development

We are going to take a few minutes to discuss 4 aspects of development determined by the Center on the Developing Child at Harvard University.

Development is a highly interactive process, and life outcomes are not determined solely by genes

The environment in which one develops before and soon after birth, provides experiences that chemically modify certain genes. So, while genetic factors influence the human development, environmental factors have the ability to alter family inheritance.

While attachments to their parents are primary, young children can also benefit significantly from relationships with other responsive caregivers within and outside the family

Close relationships with other nurturing and reliably available adults do not interfere with the strength of a young child’s primary relationship with his or her parents. In fact, they can promote young children’s social and emotional development. But also, frequent disruptions in care, high staff turnover, and poor- quality interactions in child care can undermine a child’s ability to establish secure expectations about whether and how their needs will be met.

Even infants and young children are affected adversely when significant stresses threaten their family and caregiver environments

Adverse fetal and early childhood experiences can lead to physical and chemical disruptions to the brain that can last a lifetime. These increase the risk of impairments in learning and behavior, along with poor physical and mental health outcomes.

A great deal of brain architecture is shaped during the first three years after birth, but the window of opportunity for its development does not close on a child’s third birthday

Basic aspects of brain function, such as the ability to see or hear, and some emotional development, do depend on the early years. However, brains continue to develop well into adolescence and adulthood. So even though the principle “earlier is better than later” still applies, most domains of development remain open far past 3 years old. We are also capable of learning ways to “work around” earlier impacts well into adult years.
